For this reason, my discussion today will be
directed at outlining such an approach, estimat¬
ing its cost, and suggesting possible steps to im¬
plement it. Perhaps with this as a background,
some of the fertile minds in this room and else¬
where in education and broadcasting, can refine
and improve my suggestions in order to bring the
most urgent necessity of our times into being
more quickly.
To get educational television off the ground,
on a national scale, will require a massive injec¬
tion of money, in the area of two-and-a-half bil¬
lion dollars. It would be one of the most prudent
investments we, as a nation, could make, because
it would offer our best hope—and surely our
most realistic one—for achieving a substantial up¬
grading of educational quality on a short-run
basis and at a cost we could afford.
This $21/2 billion investment would buy:
Another 150 ETV stations giving us a nation¬
wide educational network comparable to our
nation-wide commercial networks. Approxi¬
mate cost: $100 million.
Branching closed-circuit systems for all schools
in the United States. Approximate cost: $900
million.
Studios and television tape centers for origi¬
nating programs for these closed-circuit sys¬
tems. Approximate cost: $900 million.
Television receivers for our million-and-a-quar-
ter classrooms. Approximate cost: $600 mil¬
lion.
